ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Enhancement of GaAs/InGaAs quantum well emission by disordered gold nanoparticle arrays

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering

Affiliation.OrgName: Institute of Materials Research and Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Coupling effect of surface plasmon (SP) with InGaAs/GaAs QW emission is demonstrated experimentally. The SP resonance is generated by disordered arrays of Au nanodisks on the InGaAs/GaAs QW surface. More than twofold enhancement in QW PL is observed. Theoretical simulations also indicated that the disordered arrays of Au structures enlarged the cone angle for which light can be radiated out. The larger angle enhances the PL intensity.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Recently, the study of the effects of field enhancement in the vicinity of metallic nanostructures has attracted much attention. It is well understood that this field enhancement is caused by the collective oscillations of electrons in metals structured on the subwavelength scale, which is called localized surface plasmon (LSP). LSP can induce local optical fields which may exceed the average optical fields of the incident light by orders of magnitude. It has been demonstrated that various optical effects can be enhanced near the resonantly excited metal nanoparticles. Single metallic nanoparticles were reported to be able to enhance the nearby electrical field and photoluminescence intensity of a single active molecule [1]. However, the effect caused by a single metallic nanoparticle is relatively weak. Subsequently, ordered arrays of metallic nanoparticles with a separation comparable to the free space wavelength of radiation have been predicted [2] and observed [3, 4] to give spectrally narrow directional resonances which is useful for high sensitivity spectroscopic application [5, 6]. Recently, ordered arrays of metallic nanoparticles were also applied to enhance photoluminance from optoelectronic devices, especially in the visible range, and obtained great progress [7]. However, in the near infrared range, for example, emissions at 980Â nm from LEDs, the experimental results still lacks. Here, investigation of LSP effects generated by ordered and disordered Au nanodisk arrays on InGaAs/GaAs QW structures is reported. More than twofold enhancement of PL has been observed from the sample with the disordered Au nanodisks.

For fluorescence enhancement applications, closely spaced ordered arrays have a significant disadvantage since the energy from the excited active layer is coupled into âdark modesâ and gets dissipated. For the case of a periodic structure with a square lattice, Khurgin and Sun [8] have indicated theoretically that the modes with q

However, when some degree of disorder is introduced to the lattice, LSP modes mixing will occur, which transforms partially some of the dark modes into bright modes. In this paper, we report on the direct evidence of the effects of a disorder in the arrangement of nanostructures in enhancing light emission.

Section1.Heading: Experiment
Section1.Para:
In our experiments, three samples were studied. Sample A is a InGa
$$_{0.18}$$
0.18
As
$$_{0.82}$$
0.82
/GaAs quantum well (QW) grown by molecular beam epitaxy technique, which consisted of 12 nm In
$$_{0.18}$$
0.18
Ga
$$_{0.82}$$
0.82
As (herein after referred as InGaAs) well and 20 nm GaAs cap layer. Sample B has a disordered array of Au nanodisks fabricated on the surface of the as-grown InGaAs/GaAs QW. Sample C has an ordered array of Au nanodisks on the top of as-grown InGaAs/GaAs QW. Laser interference lithography (LIL) was employed to pattern the Sample B and the Sample C. A double exposure process was used to generate a square lattice of photoresist. The lattice constant can be controlled by laser wavelength and the angle between the incident beam and the reflected beam. Near circular openings of photoresist were formed due to the surface tension after development. Au was deposited on the patterns and Au disks were formed after a lift-off process. In our process, there exists a number of ways to fabricate disordered Au nanostructures because the residual photoresist after development can affect the disk formation. In one method, the disordered Au nanodisks (Sample B) were formed by directly depositing 10Â nm Au on the patterns generated by the LIL. The nearly ordered Au disks (Sample C) were formed by depositing Au on the photoresist patterns after O
$$_{2}$$
2
RIE treatment was performed on it. Figure 1a and b shows SEM images of Sample B and Sample C, respectively. It is seen that disordering in the array of the Au nanodisks occurs both in shape and position on top of the InGaAs/GaAs QW surface for Sample B. The coverage of the Au nanodisks (area ratio to the underlying GaAs surface) for Sample B and Sample C are 14Â % and 44Â %, respectively.
Fig. 1
a The SEM image of random Au nanodisk arrays for Sample B. b The SEM image of ordered Au nanodisk arrays for Sample C
The reflectance spectrum was measured by a UVâIR microspectrophotometer at normal incidence. A commercial RPM2000 rapid photoluminescence mapper was employed to collect the PL signal.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Figure 2 shows the PL spectra of Sample A (blue dotted curve), Sample B (black dashed curve), and Sample C (red solid curve) measured at room temperature. For Sample A, the QW emission peak was observed at 993Â nm. Strong enhancement of the QW PL was observed for Sample B. The peak intensity increased by 2.02 times that of Sample A, with QW emission peak wavelength blue-shifted to 982Â nm. However, for the Sample C, the QW emission peak intensity decreased to almost 10Â % of that of Sample A, and its peak wavelength blue-shifted to 986Â nm.
Fig. 2
PL spectra of Sample A (blue dotted curve), Sample B (black dashed curve), and Sample C (red solid curve)

If we consider the surface emission area, for Sample B, in which area ratio of Au nanodisk to the underlying GaAs surface was
$$\sim $$
â¼
14Â %, both of the excitation and emitting light would be reduced by 14Â %. Therefore, the real enhancement of PL for the Sample B should be more than 2.02 times. For Sample C, of which area ratio was 44Â %, would reduce by 44Â %. However, the peak intensity of the InGaAs QWs emission from Sample C decreased by nearly 90Â % as compared to Sample A. The PL intensity difference may be attributed to the coupling effect between QW emission and LSP. The excitation energy in the QW is transferred into the LSP modes of the Au nanodisks if the energy of LSPs is close to the band gap energy of InGaAs QW. It leads to a hybridized excitation. First, the excited electronâhole pairs generated in the QW relax by emitting energy into LSP modes. This LSP resonance energy coupling mode subsequently offers a large density of states with a fast coupling rate. It provides a fast path for electronâhole recombination. The energy can be coupled to both the LSP bright and dark modes. However, only those coupled to the LSP bright modes can be radiated out in the form of light. Those coupled to LSP dark modes would be thermally dissipated. Therefore, during this process, not only the degree of localization of an average SP mode for a given wavelength plays an important role, but also the degree to which the light can be extracted out by bright modes [8], is important.

To verify the enhancement mechanism, measurement of reflectance spectrum for Sample B and Sample C was conducted. The reflectance measurement was normalized with respect to a standard Aluminum mirror. Figure 3 shows the experimental results. A broad dip is observed from 800 to 1,300Â nm for Sample B (black dashed curve), while a relatively narrow and deep dip is clearly seen from 900 to 1,200Â nm for Sample C (red solid curve). The reflectance spectra reveal that the wavelengths around the InGaAs QW emission peak wavelength (993Â nm) coincide with the dip in the reflectance of Sample C. It is expected that efficient coupling between LSP and QW emission would enhance the QW PL intensity. Instead, the QW PL intensity from Sample C was decreased dramatically. This may be attributed to the greater interparticle coupling between more closely spaced Au nanodisks which enhanced the field in the lateral gaps between the Au nanodisks, and thus less light was extracted from the sample surface. If only the density of state is considered, there would be lower PL intensity from Sample B. However, the random Au structure induces the larger angle of bright mode LSP which allowed more light to be radiated out. In the case of Sample B, due to the disordering, the dispersion relation becomes

Fig. 3
Reflectance spectrum of Sample B (black dashed curve) and of Sample C (red solid curve)

To obtain further support for our conjecture, numerical simulation was performed using finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) software, Lumerical. The geometry used for this three-dimensional simulation was based on SEM images for Sample B and Sample C. Electrical dipoles (centered at 993Â nm, with a span of 60Â nm), representing the QW emission, were placed to 20Â nm below the surface of GaAs, and acted as light sources in this system. Light intensity in the center plane of Au nanodisks and in the plane 100Â nm above the Au nanodisks for both samples were monitored to observe how much light can be emitted out. The far field projections for both samples were also collected to see the angular distribution of the collected signal. Figure 4 shows the simulated spectra of the electrical field intensity as a function of wavelengths in the different planes for both samples. Comparing the electrical field intensity in the plane of Au nanodisks for Samples B and C (black dashed curve in Fig. 4a and b), we can see that more light is confined in the plane of Au nanodisks for Sample C, which agrees well with our conjecture. It is observed from Fig 4a that about half of the energy in the plane of Au nanodisks was radiated out into free space for Sample B. From Fig 4b, less than 5% of energy was radiated out for Sample C. Although high electrical field was confined by the Au nanodisks for Sample C, much of the light was confined in the lateral direction due to the interparticle coupling between the closely spaced Au nanodisks, which is the disadvantage for coupling of LSP with QW emission [9]. Insets of Fig. 4a and b show the far field patterns for Samples B and C, respectively. It is observed that the angle of the bright mode for Sample B is 10
$$^{\circ }$$
â
bigger than that for Sample C, and it would allow more energy be radiated out for Sample B. Thus, we believe that the enhancement of the PL intensity for Sample B is indeed caused by the randomness of Au structure. Further investigation on the carrier decay dynamics by time resolved PL peak intensity decay measurement will be carried out and reported elsewhere.
Fig. 4
a Spectra of electric field intensity as a function of wavelengths in the plane of Au nanodisks (black dashed curve) and 100Â nm above the Au nanodisks (red solid curve) for Sample B. Inset shows the far field projection for Sample B. b Spectra of electric field intensity as a function of wavelengths in the plane of Au structure (black dashed curve) and 100Â nm above the Au structure (red solid curve) for Sample C. Inset shows the far field patterns for Sample C

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In conclusion, we have demonstrated the enhancement of the light output from a disordered array of Au nanodisks on InGaAs/GaAs QW, and showed that with disordering, the exit angle of LSP bright modes is enlarged. Subsequently, the degree of LSP coupling to the outside world is significantly enhanced. In our experiment, more than two times enhancement of PL intensity has been achieved. To our best knowledge, this is the first report on the PL enhancement from InGaAs/GaAs QWs by LSP generated from randomly distributed metallic nanostructure.
